awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: RUI: Bulldog Mote- Low Power Sensor Node and design Methodologies for Wireless Sensor Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) are composed of a significant number of nodes deployed in a widespread area in which not all nodes are directly connected. WSNs have been widely employed in numerous real world smart applications that greatly impact many areas of humanity, including health care monitoring, forest fire detection, air pollution monitoring, landslide detection, and structural health monitoring. However, limited battery life and inefficient power management of the sensor nodes continue to be major concerns in the further development of WSNs. This project aims to design a new low-power sensor node, the Bulldog Mote, using attractive low power techniques, such as energy harvesting, clock scheduling, and dynamic voltage scheduling, implemented through all WSN design layers. The WSN and all its subsystems containing the newly designed Bulldog Motes will be methodologically tested on forest fire detection and/or smart watering applications. The impact of this project will be further strengthened by: (1) embedding low-power design technologies in substantial systems from major industry parties, (2) enhancing curriculum development with improved courses and senior projects, (3) disseminating research results through online tutorial, peer referred publications, and open-source website, (4) reaching out to K-12 students and underrepresented minority groups through open houses and summer camps, and (5) supporting women and minority students in research. Finally, subsequent comprehensive low-power design model and procedures will be developed for designers to create and improve designs of other embedded devices under tight power constrains.   

The successful application of WSN heavily relies on efficiently designed communication protocols and energy aware node architecture. This project addresses the design and implementation of the following components: (1) efficient low-power methodologies implemented throughout all WSNs' design layers from the application to the physical layer, (2) a new WSN sensor node, the Bulldog Mote, created using various low power methodologies, and (3) energy harvesting technologies for sensor node architecture. A low power design model will be created to design such embedded devices and made available to educators, students and engineers working in related areas. Furthermore, this research will provide the knowledge necessary to design enhanced sensor nodes for WSNs in terms of power consumption and communication ability. The same low-power design techniques can be used for a variety of other power constrained applications, such as consumer electronics and medical devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
WSNs (Wireless Sensor Networks) are widely employed in military sensing, environmental applications, structural health monitoring, health and medical applications, and home applications. 

The major goals of the project are the design and implementation of the following components: (1) efficient low-power methodologies implemented throughout all WSN design layers from application to the physical layer, (2) a new WSN sensor node, the Bulldog Mote, created using various low power methodologies, and (3) energy harvesting technologies for sensor node architecture.

A Bulldog mote system has been successfully designed, assembled, and tested. A WSN formed by the Bulldog motes has been established to test the efficiency of the new low-power schemes and new energy technologies. Satisfactory results have been collected and published in peer-reviewed journals, conferences and on the project website. Basic energy harvesting technologies, such as MPPT (Maximum Power Point Tracking) algorithms, including Perturb & Observe and Incremental Conductance were studied in the beginning. Both algorithms were investigated and simulated using PSIM and a prototype system was built and tested. First and second PCBs (Printed Circuit Boards) were designed and tested. In addition, advanced MPPT algorithms and battery management algorithms were developed and tested using PSIM, and MATLAB/Simulink Real-time based software. Additionally, the third PCB board was designed and tested for the final integration. Finally, the artificial neural network-based MPPT algorithm was developed and tested.  The final PCB with advanced energy harvesting software algorithms was designed, built, and validated.

This project has successfully enhanced research activities and collaboration at the California State University-Fresno in WSN systems, Wireless Communication, Embedded Systems, New Energy harvesting, and Power Engineering. The project directly impacts education and research programs in Electrical and Computer Engineering and has benefitted many graduate and undergraduate students, most of which are from underrepresented groups.

As many as 13 graduate students and 7 undergraduate students have been directly involved in the project working on the WSN algorithms, Bulldog Mote system design, New Energy Harvesting, and Power Engineering projects. Many other students benefitted from the project through senior design projects, updated course contents, and semester projects. The PIs and the student research assistants published 17 research papers in peer-review journals and conferences and delivered various keynote speaking and technical presentations to local, national, and international audiences. The PIs and the student research assistants won several awards, including best paper award, best section, and/or best symposium presentation awards. 

Several courses were updated with the related technologies and projects. Students gained real-world experience in these courses, including ECE144 (Embedded Operating Systems), ECE174 (Computer Architectures), ECE 274 (High-Performance Computer Architectures), ECE121(Energy Conversion), ECE121L (Energy Conversion Lab), ECE153 (Power Electronics), and ECE253 (Advanced Power Electronics). These courses allow students to bridge the gap between the knowledge they learn in class and real-world applications. 

The results and progress of the Bulldog Mote project have been disseminated through various media and resources, peer-reviewed conferences and journals, open houses, project websites, workshops, and webinars. The PI, Dr. Nan Wang, presented the Bulldog mote project in the LIVE WEBCAST: STEM-NET "CSU NSF Research at Undergraduate Institutions (RUI)" to the students and Faculty audiences from 23 California State University Campuses in Sep 2021. He delivered several keynote speeches and plenary speakings at several IEEE conferences in the last three years across America, Canada, and China. The PIs and student research assistants also presented their papers at conferences, workshops, symposiums, and open houses.

The project provides the necessary foundation from which further collaborations can be developed between the faculty at Fresno State and other institutions to continue the work and submit additional proposals. The PI, Dr. Nan Wang, is leading an effort to apply for the NSF Crest grant to establish a research center on Advanced Nano Material Technologies and Smart WSN Systems. The co-PI, Dr. Woonki Na worked with faculty from the UC Merced, Cal-poly Pomona, and Fresno State to prepare an NSF grant proposal for the Center for Advanced Research on Wide Bandgap Materials (AlGaN/GAN and Sic/GaN) and devices development. Other internal/external proposals are also in preparation or submitted. 

The Bulldog Mote project will benefit current and future projects including smart sensor network design for health monitoring of nanomaterials and structures, agriculture applications and wildfire detection, as well as new energy harvesting, and smart power grid and storage.  More students, especially those from underrepresented groups, will benefit from the further developed smart WSN systems and new energy technologies. 

Improving researchers's ability to exploit capacity and knowledge brings broader impacts within and beyond the immediate subject areas. Experience gained from the Bulldog Mote project will spur new collaborations and educational activities for undergraduate and graduate research, teaching, training, and sharing of data with a larger community of researchers. New modes of research collaboration can be developed to further Fresno State?s contributions to the ?grand challenges? facing society.
